reviewText:
Imagine a group of people really liked Counter-Strike but wanted it to be like Ghost in the Shell and you have NEOTOKYO°

I know it's frowned upon to compare it to Counter-Strike but that's really the closest thing there is to compare to it.

General run down on gameplay:

* Round Based

* If you die you are out of the round

* There are 3 classes, each with it's own perks, disadvantages and equipment

* If you are not careful you will die really really quick

* There is an active cameo ability 2 of the classes get to use that makes you transparent and hard to see, moving around though will get you spotted

* Each class has it's own vision mode (such as heat vision to track people through smoke grenades)

* You unlock weapons the better you do in a round and unlocks are reset once the map changes

* Teams are pretty much identical

* Capture the flag is the most popular gamemode, twist being the flag (a female robot torso with no arms) can show the holder where everyone is on the map after a few seconds of hodling it

If you can get some friends to play with you and use the mic chat it's a lot of fun and rounds can get intense.

reviewText:
Fast-paced team shooter set in near future Japan, where players either take control of Government security forces or a rogue special forces unit within the military. With pushBAK's[www.pushbak.org] distinct cyberpunk style and accompanied by a two album OST by Ed Harrison[edharrison.bandcamp.com]

While often compared with Counter-Strike, the only things these two games share is an engine and round format for its primary game mode (Capture the Ghost). NEOTOKYO's complexity and depth derives from its in-game features (invisibility, vision modes, etc...) and engine functionality, and less from its weapon handling (which is basic at best). Old Source rules here, 6 years past its initial release players have adopted playstyles that make the most of how Source engine used to deal with movement; bunnyhopping, wall-strafing, air-strafing, wiggle-walking are commonly deployed situationally alongside the game's core features. Positioning and movement is key and a heightened situational awareness is required (which can be greatly helped by a little teamwork). The game can be played at a blistering pace between as little as 6 players on many of its deeply dynamic maps.

reviewText:
This game has a really steep learning curve. 61 hours on record since I've written this, and only now can I say that I can play relatively competently. This game isn't for people who just want to pick up and play.

However, if you git gud, this game is fun as hell. Plus, it's a free stand-alone mod. So hell, there's really no downside to downloading it.

The comparison to CS is made a lot, but really only because it's the only thing close to it. Games of Neotokyo are extremely dynamic, and each round can go in any direction. The first round, you could spend the whole 2 minutes slowly picking off stragglers. The second, you could get your whole team wiped out by a recon det-rush. The maps were designed for easy flanking. Because of this, teams need to adapt to their enemy strategies, block off route (A) because their recons bunny hop through there. They know they're blocking off route (A) and coming around through route (G). etc.

What makes the game the most fun though is the ranking and class system. You gain experience for killing, capturing the flag (ghost), surviving the round. Unlike CS, you unlock weapons through what your rank is. This doesn't necesarrily give any player a distinct advantage. There are Assault players who swear by the ZR Silenced, a rank 1 gun, and for myself, whenever I play recon, I won't play by anything other than the SRM, another rank 1 gun.

Unless you're playing recon, and you're really confident in your bunnyhopping skills, you literally need to stay by your team mates. It's way too easy to die in this game, and believe me, sitting out for 15 minutes a game is not fun. If you want to stay alive, get a mic, and start talking. If the ghost is close to you, pick it up, and call out positions.

If you're a beginner and you want to learn the ropes of how to play neotokyo, then I suggest going to Agiel's Deathmatch Server. It's usually dead, but it lets you learn the ins and outs of how brutal combat can be, and how to move faster.

Overall: 8/10. It's not for everybody, but it definitely should have more players than it does now.

reviewText:
I'll try to keep this review as objective as possible.

This game is multiplayer first person shooter. First that you will encounter is the classes that are shared among many games and can be basically described as light, medium and heavy. Apart from most obvious differences - selection of weapons, armor and speed, thing that makes it original is their visions. Each of those visions doesn’t give you a boost like some games like to call “special abilities” because it depends about how well you will learn to use them. Recon has a night vision, and in a world of gamma and brightness adjustments it’s most obsolete function, but so it had to be for a class than compensate it in other areas. Medium or as they call it assault have a motion vision. While it’s most useful of all visions, its grayed out colors are disadvantage for every non-moving enemy that could be lurking near you. Heavy class named support had a thermal vision which would be most useful if there wasn’t for one thing – the cloak which makes other 2 classes predator-like invisible (with a disadvantage of making big noise when turning cloak off/on), and even more often harder to spot with this vision turned on.

The maps are more into simulating real architecture angles then making battle more fluid. You will find a lot of corners, dark places, hard-to-reach-but-can-be-done areas and especially choke points which will encourage more camping and demand more twitch reflexes a la counter strike then target leading. It might even turn the game into more team deathmatching then capture the flag, which is a bit shameful since that part is centered a lot more on better movement and tactical decisions among teammates. It has to be mentioned that with capturing flag players in whole team are awarded for more points for unlocking weapons then by simple wiping out the other team, as it can award you for as much as 10 points (1p=1kill).

This game plays and feels like a mod. It has a lot of originality and personality that comes from smaller tighter developing teams, especially in its design of dystopian Ghost in Shell world, but it also shows areas for improvement (or to better put it – area for balancing) which could easily turn it from good game into great one which would be worth a few bucks, pounds or euros. As it is free, there is no need to complain about that, but free to play games are turning into more and more of a “thing” this days and it may get harder to draw new players on tight budget.

Now the subjective part:
The community has been amazing, you will meet most wonderful people here, from child molesters, serial killers to rapists, I really felt at home here and they kept this game alive all this years.

reviewText:
NEOTOKYO offers some refreshing FPS dynamics between playable classes and objective-centered gameplay, accentuated by a surprisingly large choice in mapped environments. Its community (a rather small one, I admit) consists largely of people willing to engage in teamplay, which does players' experiences a lot of good. I'd say the best thing about the mod is its setting, however. A cybernetics-focused and futuristic look at Tokyo and its surroundings, with a war raging between two groups: extremist nationalists by the name of JINRAI, who's aim is to perform a coup and establish a military dictatorship; and the Interior Ministry's National Security Forces (NSF), who attempt to maintain the political status quo and thus fight off the extremist forces. The mod's art (modeling, maps, sounds, etc) complements its setting extremely well, and succeeds in immersing you within the set universe, even if its story is minimal at best. Even if the game's content does not succeed in convincing you of its ambience, it is hard to deny the large amounts of work that the developers put into the creation of said assets.

NEOTOKYO is by no means revolutionary, however, and one should not enter its universe with high hopes or broad expectations. It's a simple shooter with some fun and fresh mechanics (particularly its recurring objective and the classes players can choose from) with well-done art direction. That said, its potential is great, but is held back by the mod's age and lack of significant updates. Let's hope its steam release proves to be a communitary catalyst for things to get clicking once more. And even if it doesn't, it's still bloody free-- so give it a shot, people.

One of my favorite games to play... and one that's really hard to recommend.

I dunno, this game feels right, it always has. Back before the Steam release, when there were only two servers with damn near no one on them 'scept at the right times. It's got bugs, there's some questionable design decisions, but all in all there's nothing REALLY like it on the market. That being said, you can EASILY kill the entire team with the weakest gun in the game if you just do it properly, and there's nothing stopping you from killing a foe wielding a more powerful weapon and taking it. Most of the difficulty comes down to knowing the maps, knowing where the ambush spots are, knowing where to look, and knowing where to go. This comes with time, but it can be frustrating to learn. The community of crazies who stick with this game too are a pretty helpful and chill bunch for the most part; you have to be to stick with a dead project this long. Neotokyo is a free to play multiplayer FPS game that offers a high emphasis on teamwork and tactical combat. The game has similarities to Blacklight: Retribution, and Counter-Strike.

~The gameplay~

The game features three classes. Recon, Assault, and Support. These three classes are pretty well balanced. Recon offers endless sprint, longer cloaking, various SMGs and Assault Rifles with silenced variants, two sniper rifles, a knife, and light armor, with the addition of a cloak, and night vision. Assault provides you with assault rifles, SMGs, shotguns, and one sniper rifle, as well as a frag grenade, knife, and medium armor, with limited sprint, night vision, and cloak. Support provides you with Assault Rifles, Shotguns, an LMG, smoke grenades, and heavy armor, but you cannot sprint, and night vision/cloak are traded out for a thermal visor.

But then we get to the weapons. The game offers a fair number of weapons, but the problem is that very few of them feel like they're actually worth using. None of the three SMGs feel particularly useful, the M41 (semi-auto combat rifle) is actually fairly bad, shotguns aren't really worth using either, making the majority of your battles be done with Assault Rifles. The problem, is that the default assault rifle is essentially the best weapon in the entire game, unless you get the Support's LMG, or the bolt-action sniper rifle, both of which are exceptionally more powerful if used correctly.

The combat, on the other hand, ranges from interesting and thrilling, to boring and dull. In some matches, you'll find yourself with a fun, and cooperative team that really makes you feel like you're working with allies. Then there's other matches where some child squealing into his mic rushes behind you the moment you spawn and teamkills you with his knife, leaving you to sit there, and watch the entire match, wishing you could actually do something, since, like Counter-Strike, there are no respawns.

reviewText:
A game about two teams of Japanese men who fight over a female robot-torso complete with boobs and nipples. What's not to love?

Okay bad jokes aside, this is a good game. If you are playing this, make sure to hit the forums for info on getting to servers.

Anyway, Neo Tokyo takes place in an Anime-style Cyberpunk future, where two teams of Japanese special forces fight each other over the Ghost which is (as mentioned before) a female robot torso. This isn't a weird sex toy though, this torso allows you to see enemies nearby, at the cost of a primary weapon, and displaying your postion to everyone on the map. The objective is to either capture this robot, or kill the enemy team (this game has permadeath like Counter Strike).

This game plays like a more tactical Counter Strike. There is no crosshair unless you zoom in, you can die quickly, and team work is the key to success. Every kill or capture will allow you to rank up, allowing the player to aquire more weapons.

The community is really friendly too. I've even seen people give turtorials to new players. Of course this is only my personal experience, but it has been a good one.

There are three classes, Recon (light), Assault (medium) and Support (heavy). Each class gets their own weapon roster, vision modes, cloaking abilities, and movement speed.

A bunch of reviewers (who have IMO probably haven't played the game for very long) will state the classes are imbalanced. This is not true. Sure, Recon can reach places that others can't, but he is pretty weak in direct combat, and his arsenal is restricted. They also get the worst (IMO) vision mode, so they require a lot of skill to use.

Map varierty is great. From open fields, to confied market places and even a bullet train. All the maps feel good, and the developers have put a lot of effort into making each map feel interesting.

The graphics for today look kinda 'meh' but the artstyle compensates. It looks vibrate, and interesting. It's like you've stepped into a Sci-Fi Anime/Manga.

My complaints of this game would be that most of the development team does not seem to be around anymore, so updates are unlikely. I would also say the guns sound pretty weak, and some of the weapons unlocked by the last rank are a little overpowered. I mean the Auto shotgun can tear enemies apart at short range, the bolt action sniper rifle can kill recons in one shot and the LMG can easily tear enemies apart. It's certainly not a deal breaker and the game is still about skill but it does make it harder to join mid-match.

Considering it's a mod, I'd give this a 10/10. I've had more fun with this than most other 'F2P' games. It's got good balance, an awesome art style, a small, but active community, and there is a lot of fun to be had.

reviewText:
The obvious comparison of this game is to Counterstrike (and it's various derivatives), due to the round structuring, and other near-future shooters like Blacklight:Retribution. There are undeniably some similarities, but let me highlight some of the major features built into NEOTOKYO's design.

1. Class dynamic - class differences are subtle but significant enough to matter. Supports can sponge enough extra bullets and will often prevail in brute force firefights, but this trades off against a lack of mobility. Conversely, Recons have the speed to gain initiative but must rely on that to set up favourable encounters. On the strategic level, differing class access to weapons means that rounds see an evolution in applicable tactics as teams unlock higher tier weapons. The class system also caters to different playstyles as well.

2. Pacing and Ghost Control - Different class speeds mean that map chokepoints are reached at different times (whereas in games where all players have fixed speeds, initial encounters have a definable range). In addition, the semi-random nature of ghost spawns make each match dynamic, with some matches featuring a more natural attacking or defending team.

3. Map Design - the art direction and map design is much more interesting. Maps are labryinthe and multi-leveled, and generally require a team approach; it's often very difficult for an individual to find a spot immune to flanking

4. Lack of respawns - I may be in the minority here, but I think this actually helps out new players. A strong, dominating player can be taken out by a lucky shot or by being swarmed and will be a non-factor in the rest of the match. This sort of scenario isn't possible in a respawn environment, where weak players are ultimately a drag on the team.


While a lot of tactical shooter skills may transfer over, these are the elements that NEOTOKYO features and it will likely provoke a love-it or hate-it reaction. The pacing and map design overall have a lot of subtlety and there's just something very Zen or even wabi-sabi about the minimalistic game design that just makes it feel right given the cyberpunk Japan setting. It's undeniably rough around the edges, but it's generally a really unique experience as FPS games go.

reviewText:
A very fun, tactical shooter reminicent of Counter Strike when you first start playing. When you get into it though, you find out its a much different game with a bigger emphasis on teamwork and player roles.

Part of what makes this game different is its game mode, Capture The Ghost, and the different playstyles of the three classes. In Counter Strike, you do not pick a class for your character, you can only buy weapons and gear to create your own role. In this game, there is no money (so no eco rounds! Rejoice!) but there is a rank-up system that unlocks more weapons as you score higher.

Now, you are probably thinking that an unlock system would break the game and allow for huge landslide victories, and it would if the starting weapons for each class weren't so damn good. With the exception of the MPN (the first SMG) and Recon's sidearm every weapon is viable in some way. There are a few imbalances, namely with the auto shotgun, but most weapons feel very balanced as well. Don't get me wrong, the weapons you unlock are technically better in some ways, but there is nothing wrong with some of the low-rank weapons. And trust me when I say that this game will feel janky at first because the damage of weapons goes beyond your typical understanding of FPS balance. For instance, sometimes silencers hinder the gun (SRM-S) and sometimes they buff it directly (ZR-S). Its really convoluted.

Since this game is also in a cyberpunk setting, you get a few augmentations at your disposal, but nothing game-breaking. You have a optic camo that you can use at any time with every class but 1, and every class also has augmented vision, such as heat vision and motion vision. Heat vision can allow you to see through smoke grenades, and motion vision helps you find cloaked people very easily. The game becomes very stealth-and-surprise oriented as a result of these gameplay elements. Finding great places to cloak, hiding and confusing your enemies is the key to victory. Oh yeah, you can also lean around corners like in Rainbow Six.

The game mode, Capture The Ghost, ties into this as well. The Ghost is the robot torso and is the grey blip on your screen. If you drop a weapon and grab it, you will be able to see where enemies are through walls. Seems awesome, right? Well its not too awesome for you. First, only you can actually see the enemies positions on-screen as blips. You must call out where the enemies are to your teammates using the compass and general directions, which is arguably the hardest part about effectively using the ghost. Finally, you are marked as a red blip for every enemy on the other team, so you can become a sitting duck very fast if you pick the Ghost up without knowing what you are doing. In short, it is 1 flag CTF with a very big twist that helps teamplay immensely. Without the Ghost this game would be just a random TDM game without as much cooperation.

Capturing the Ghost helps your team by ranking them all up. Low-ranking teams, usually the losing team, can keep getting Ghost captures to rank up to the same levels as the winning team and, in turn, unlock better weapons to use against the enemies. This helps prevent the landslide victories or steamrolling that is present in many multiplayer games. It is also really awesome to pull off a Ghost cap against all odds, since it is even more helpful to your team than clutching.

There are 3 different classes, each being roles on the battlefield. There is the agile Recon that can leap very far (and even b-hop), the jack-of-all-trades Assault, and the powerhouse Support. Each have special weapons and abilities, but again to even the playing field none of these are that OP. Recon can cloak for a lot longer than assault and has a C4 that he/she can detonate along with night-vision. Assault has frags, starts with rifles unlocked, and has motion vision. Support has no cloak but makes up for this in loads of defense, high-caliber weaponry and smoke grenades. Using the heat vision while in the smoke will let you see through the smoke.

Not to mention this game has a simply beautiful art direction and a great soundtrack (by Ed Harrison) that sadly doesn't play ingame. Many of the maps are very well designed, though some are a little too gimmicky (Bullet, anyone?) they all look fantastic. Some might initally think the maps are too cluttered with LOADS of props, and they are, but this is to obscure you when you are cloaking. I love the japanese bug fight vending machine btw.

So yeah, play this game, its ♥♥♥♥in' awesome.

Before I do up a review I have a couple of disclaimers I should point out. Although my hours shown are non existant I used to play this back when it was first released a number of years ago. Also right now it's unplayable for me as there is only one Oceanic server and it's been dead the past couple of nights. Because of this I'll be basing my review on my time spent on this mod before it hit steam.

To begin, this game oozes style. Personally I'm a massive Cyberpunk junkie. Bladerunner, Neuromancer, Johnny Mnemonic, Deus Ex, Ghost in the Shell, Bubblegum Crisis, etc. You name it I've seen/played/read it, so it comes to no suprise I instantly fell in love with the theme of the game. It's more then apparent NEOTOKYO, even in name alone draws everything from Japanese cyberpunk, and that alone is why I fell in love with this game. From the decor, to the weapons, right down to the cyborg torso 'flag', it screams Masamune Shirow. Even the soundtrack, which is something I usually don't bother with, especially with FPS, is beautiful. I still listen to it even though I haven't touched the game for quite a while.

Now gameplay? I'm a bit on the fence with gameplay. At this time, I personally have around 50 hours of play on Neotokyo. I have never had any experience running a server or any other kind of role in the community besides playing.

Overall I really enjoy the experience of playing Neotokyo. The setting is refreshing, the maps are interesting, the weapons and equipment are fun to use, the soundtrack is hypnotizing, etc. However there are a few things that are lacking in this mod--which is expected, as it is a Free-To-Play game made by a small group of developers.

Neotokyo is a cyper-punk tactical shooter set in Japan of the future. It is about conflict between two factions which are--essentially--in disagreement over whether Japan should have a military force or not.

Things I Enjoy & Things That Are Good:    the ambiance created by the interesting maps (dark cyper-punk feel)
overall gameplay (methodical, light-tactical shooter)
the music (I never was into electronic or cyper-punk music before, but I really enjoy Neotokyo's Soundtrack--it's free!)
runs well on low-end PC's (currently I play on a Pavilion G6 Notebook (so it's a laptop): 4GB RAM, Intel HD Graphics 3000, four 2nd gen Intel Core i3-2350M processors @2.30 GHz :O much hardcore, so pro, wow)
Things That I Think Should be Fixed:    some minor technical issues (ie: leaning doesn't always work; player and ghost icons should be more transparent so you can see things better; some UI glitches)
more community interaction (ie: formal clan system; messaging system; friends system; player level/experience levels)
more gamemodes (there currently is only Capture-the-Ghost)
Things That Can't Really Be Fixed Directly:    number of players (the community is fairly small but there is a pretty dedicated group of people who play regularlly)
number of active servers (due to the low number of players at a time, sometimes there aren't many active servers)

reviewText:
Worth downloading for the soundtrack alone.

It's also an amazing round based FPS with an emphasis on tactical play over gunplay and reflexes. There's 3 distinct classes (Recon, Assault, Support) each with their own strengths and purposes. Recon is fast and agile with access to thermo-optic camouflage and night vision, while support is a slow juggernaut that sacrifices sprinting for a smoke grenade, thermal cam and stronger armor. Assault is a balance between the two and uses both thermo-optic camouflage and a motion detector.

There's an XP system that allows you to unlock more weapons as the round goes on, but it resets every game. You get XP through kills, assists, surviving the round and completing objectives.

There's two different gamemodes: Team Deathmatch and Capture The Ghost, a sort of Capture The Flag variant where you pursue the upper half of your very own android waifu.

Most maps are centered around CTG and the maps themselves are pretty damn good. Expect lots of sneaky flanking and prolonged, exciting firefights at chokepoints.

While the gameplay is great, Neotokyo's best aspect is the atmosphere. It nails the cyberpunk vibe with its tight urban environments filled with flashy neon lights, various electronic clutter, thoughtful graffiti and references to Japanese pop culture. When you're not fighting in ♥♥♥♥ riddled streets, you'll be shooting it out on top of skyscrapers, in military facilities or even in and out a traditional shrine. The two factions, the NSF and Jinrai are as badass as you'd expect. While the NSF is a civilian special-ops group fighting for the government and Japan's constitution, the Jinrai are a nationalistic, militarist terrorist organisation with a clear Samourai vibe in their attitude and looks. There's heavy influences from Ghost in the Shell and it definitely feels like a 2035 Japan. So if you dig the whole cyberpunk subgenre like I do, or if you're just a big weeb, you'll absolutely love it.

Since it runs on the 2006 version of the Source Engine, the game is very outdated graphics and technology wise. Though, that doesn't stop it from looking good aesthetically and that fantastic vibe is still there (in the same way that Half-Life 2 and Deus Ex manage to have that special cyberpunk vibe to them despite looking old). Unfortunately, it does mean that crashes are kinda frequent.

The community is pretty small but there's usually 2-3 servers with lots of activity on them. It's also super friendly and helpful, but due to its nature as a tight, niche game you can expect a vocal minority of elitists.

Did I mention the soundtrack is superb? 'Cos it is. Ed Harrison is a musical genius. You can listen to it in game by typing !radio in the chat. The Ghost in the Shell soundtrack, Industrial, Noise, Drone, Hip-Hop and Jazz all fit the game nicely if you're looking to listen to something else while playing.

It's free to play so be sure to try the game out. You might just find yourself hooked and even if it's not to your appeal, you don't lose much!

The gameplay is a bit minimal due to the one game type, lack of customization, and graphical portrayal. The game type is a variant of CTF, where your team can either capture the flag OR kill off the entire opposing team. You also only have one life per round, so use it wisely. Lack of customization speaks for itself, and the graphical portrayal, utilizing the hl2 engine, is a bit outdated, so don't expect spectacular aesthetics.

reviewText: This is definitely one of my favorite shooters of all time. The gameplay feels very tactical, as well as balanced. The main game mode is capture the ghost, where you can win the game by either capturing a ghost, or eliminating the enemy team. This is a bare bones description of the game, because there are so many more intricate mechanics that keep the game interesting, like how each of the 3 classes (light armor, medium armor, and heavy armor) play, including movement speed, their type of sight, weapon selection, amount of cloak, and many more differences. And somehow, the game still feels very balanced, in how all of the classes just synergize together. The maps are very diverse and large as well, taking on a futuristic city vibe for the most part, and it works wonderously. Lastly, the soundtrack, by far, is one of my favorite soundtracks of all time, no question. it's a perfect mix of orchestrated and electronic, and a little bit of rock, and it melds so well with the game. You should definitely give this game a shot if you want a very nice tactical shooter, and bring some friends, this game definitely needs more of a community.\nIGN: Jackchopin.\nSee you there~

reviewText:
I'd like to mention, I have many, many hours clocked in this game - previously this mod wasn't available on steam.

Imagine a slower paced counter-strike with a smaller emphasis on shooting patterns, nade patterns and budgeting. Instead, you rely heavily on the camo and detection methods, as a dynamic between the 3 classes. The main game mode revolves around obtaining the ghost - a limbless android and transporting it to a safe zone. The carrier of the said android has a limited ability to fight, but on the other hand, sees the enemy locations and can instruct their teammates. A mic is a must for this game.

Additionally, the setting is great. As others have already mentioned - Ghost in the Shell inspiration can be clearly seen.

Servers are rather unpopulated, but as long as you are in either EU or NA, there should be some people to play with daily.

I have a love/hate relationship with this game. The gameplay and style is great, though the former is subject to how well I and my team are doing in a round.

What I'm not a huge fan of, and honestly kind of keeps me from really enjoying the game to its fullest, are all of the awkward, random girly pictures scattered across some of the maps. I secretly keep hoping someone with the knowledge and same ideas will come along and mod the mod to alter or clear those images.

But, truthfully, most people don't think in that same course.

In any case, I recommend giving it a try if you want something quite different in your FPS library.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game for as long as most of the people writing these reviews, so my information may differ from others.

So currently, I have racked up a whopping two kills and a measly 3,000 deaths. But I feel like this is a pretty fair game. I've killed people many levels above me with more experience than me. Also, if you like the run-n-gun, spray-n-prey style of Call of Duty, do not play this. This takes real skill, but with that, more fun. So, there are two teams, Jinrai and NSF, (I like to call it Need Speed For,) the game will start you on opposite sides of the map, as most FPS games do. But it's weird, I've never seen an enemy on my way to the middle of the map, like the idiot I am. One of the things I LOOOOOOVED about this game is the Q and E lean mechanic. There are about two games on Steam with that mechanic: America's Army: Proving Ground, and NEOTOKYO. AA:PG is laggy as ♥♥♥ on my computer. I have a Lenovo H30. You can imagine the amount of lag that a $250 PC gets when playing a game like that. But one of the reasons why I like Source Engine games is because of how smooth it is. And the game is BEAUTIFUL. Once again, I'm not the first one to say that. But it is really stunning.

However, the video settings were somewhat disappointing. I use an Element 105 TV as my monitor, and the game's graphics significantly decrease due to the fact that it lacks a 1360x768 resolution setting. So, as you can guess, this is the beginning of the cons list. It is not a big game. It would be more fun with more people as the 32-player limit suggests, however, most of the servers have absolutely zero people playing. I found one server with 8 people. The Valve Anti-Cheat is a good thing, but it took me 5 minutes to get into the server. 5 minutes. That's about all I can think of, but please don't get it twisted.

This is an amazing game. And furthermore, it's free. The developers did an amazing job on NEOTOKYO.

8.5/10- Great game.

reviewText:
If you like Counter Strike (CS) you'll like Neotokyo (NT) for a variety of reasons.

To start off, NT is mechanically similar to CS but tactically, it's a different game entirely.

You have 3 classes each with separate vision modes, armor, and movement capabilities.

In a unique version of Capture the Flag, NT’s Capture the Ghost gives the player carrying the Ghost vision off all opposing players within 50 meters. However, all opposing players can also see where the Ghost is at all times at all distances. The vulnerable objective carrying player must now lead his/her team to victory by calling out enemies as their team heads toward the capture zone. Veteran players refer to this phenomenon as “Ghosting.”

The level design is intrinsically paired with the dynamism of each class' strength and weaknesses, as well as encouraging teamwork to provide a distinct tactical experience that isn’t available in CS.


It's a free game and well worth your time to give it a try.

reviewText:
Neotokyo is one of the few FPS games I have actually enjoyed. It has a blend of realistic tactical gameplay and stylized cyberpunk environments, abilities and characters.

Now be forewarned: This is NOT a run and gun game like COD or CSGO. The close quarters and multiple flanking routes mean you have to rely on close knit teamwork and communication to gain a tactical advantage.  The three playable classes offer well rounded playstyles giving players the ability to augment the squad in different ways and with different weapons. This  as well as various types of  class abilities such as active camoflauge, thermal vision, night vision, and motion detection, all add to the overall tactical gameplay experience.

This is a great addition for people who are looking for a well-paced tactical shooter that provides fairly realistic CQB scenarios, all while putting a very subtle but refreshing sci-fi spin on things.

reviewText:
Product received for free

This is a Half-Life 2 mod with Counter-Strike style gameplay. It seems to have had a cult following a few years ago, but it's player count is now only about 10 players average with a peak count in April of about 40.

It's clear someone put a lot of love into this mod back in the day, but I think the numerous free-to-play or reasonably priced Counter-Strike games, Source engine FPS games, and Ghost in the Shell games (this is inspired by that universe) have pulled it's audience away in various directions.

I made a goal to try all of the free-to-play FPS's on Steam during Summer 2016 looking for hidden gems. NeoTokyo would probably fit my definition of such if it had a healthy player population, but I think it's on its last breathes. Nonetheless, I plan to check back in Fall or Winter to see if anything changes.

- No way to practice offline, and at the time of this review only a handful servers, all of which are full.  So there's no way to learn the maps since as soon as you round a corner, you're killed by an invisible camper.
- No hints on what guns are effective and which are terrible; you can unload a 50 round magazine into someone, but he could have a better gun and kill you in a couple hits.  This is *very* common.

I only put in a couple hours, but I don't recommend it.  If you like CS where the best players cloak and know where to camp, try it, but expect to die a lot, and only kill one or two people.
